docs.snippet: Her celebrity sit-downs have been a staple of Academy Awards nights since 1981....
docs.lead_paragraph: Barbara Walters is calling an end to her annual Oscars interview show. Ms. Walters, 80, said Monday on "The View" that this year's "Barbara Walters Special" would be her last. Her celebrity sit-downs have been a staple of Academy Awards nights since 1981.
docs.abstract: Her celebrity sit-downs have been a staple of Academy Awards nights since 1981.

docs.snippet: The actor Brian Bedford will direct a new Broadway production of Oscar Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest", while also donning a dress and wig to play the domineering Lady Bracknell in the show....
docs.lead_paragraph: The actor Brian Bedford will direct a new Broadway production of Oscar Wilde's comedy "The Importance of Being Earnest" next season for Roundabout Theater Company, while also donning a dress and wig to play the domineering Lady Bracknell in the show.
docs.abstract: The actor Brian Bedford will direct a new Broadway production of Oscar Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest", while also donning a dress and wig to play the domineering Lady Bracknell in the show.

headline.main: Bedford to Once Again Direct, Don a Dress in 'Earnest'

docs.snippet: Pizzeria Bianco in Phoenix wins Rachael Ray's pizza contest....
docs.lead_paragraph: A tough loss for New York pizza supremacy, as Pizzeria Bianco of Phoenix has been awarded the title Best Pizza in America by the magazine Every Day With Rachael Ray, according to Lois Najarian O'Neill, a publicist for the television personality. Ms. Ray commissioned the Serious Eats founder Ed Levine and his Slice blog compatriot Adam Kuban to conduct the competition, which involved their eating at some 64 pizzerias across the United States.
docs.abstract: Pizzeria Bianco in Phoenix wins Rachael Ray's pizza contest.

headline.main: It's Pizza Oscar for Bianco, Says Rachael Ray

docs.snippet: This afternoon, before Diane Von Furstenberg’s show, I popped up to Oscar de la Renta’s showroom for a preview and, lo, the burgers and fries were inbound....
docs.lead_paragraph: This afternoon, before Diane Von Furstenberg’s show, I popped up to Oscar de la Renta’s showroom for a preview and, lo, the burgers and fries were inbound. No kidding: Mr. de la Renta and the crew, including the stylist Alex White, had ordered a delivery. They had extra. We sat around a table in the studio eating burgers off paper plates and talking about movies and this and that. Mr. de la Renta said he watched “Pretty Woman” last night. I gave him a hard time about that, naturally.
docs.abstract: This afternoon, before Diane Von Furstenberg’s show, I popped up to Oscar de la Renta’s showroom for a preview and, lo, the burgers and fries were inbound.

docs.snippet: FERNANDEZ--Sara Pena, died peacefully at home on February 10, 2010. She is survived by her cherished husband Dr. Oscar E. Fernandez, her daughter Helen Fernandez and husband Gerard Murphy, her daughter Carmen Romero and her husband Tobin Romero, h...
docs.lead_paragraph: FERNANDEZ--Sara Pena, died peacefully at home on February 10, 2010. She is survived by her cherished husband Dr. Oscar E. Fernandez, her daughter Helen Fernandez and husband Gerard Murphy, her daughter Carmen Romero and her husband Tobin Romero, her son Oscar G. Fernandez and his wife Stacey Usiak along with four grandchildren and a large and loving family in her native Colombia, where she was a lawyer and judge prior to emigrating to the United States in 1965. Visiting at Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 98-07 Ascan Ave. (corner Metropolitan Ave.), Forest Hills, NY, Saturday and Sunday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church (Ascan Ave. corner Queens Blvd.) on Monday February 15 at 10:30am. Cremation service private.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERNANDEZ, SARA PENA

docs.snippet: If there is an answer to McQueen's death, and no doubt there will be some thoughtful attempts at an explanation in the coming weeks, it will have to begin with his work....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last evening I went to Grand Central, boarded a train and went home. The past 36 hours had been depressing because of Alexander McQueen's death, and absurdly disconnected because of the shows and the chattering. If there is an answer to Mr. McQueen's death -  and no doubt there will be some thoughtful attempts at an explanation in the coming weeks - it will have to begin with his work. Looking at photographs of some of his great shows - the dance marathon show, the glass box and "Girl in the Tree" shows and of course last season's spectacular Web presentation - I think the keys are all there. It's one thing to have the vision and technical ability to realize those kinds of expressions; it is a more difficult burden to also constantly live with the emotions and ideas that those expressions embrace. And Mr. McQueen didn't just have three or four exceptional shows in his career; he had a steady run of them, and the last few seasons really saw him reaching further.
docs.abstract: If there is an answer to McQueen's death, and no doubt there will be some thoughtful attempts at an explanation in the coming weeks, it will have to begin with his work.

headline.main: New York Fashion: Wooing Penn and More
